paragraphs.text: Confessions of a teenage shoplifter.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: I couldn't help letting out a low whistle of admiration
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: when I read news that the cost of goods stolen in the average shoplifting incident is now? 241
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Bloody hell, I thought
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: as I tried to imagine how exactly you would stash that many eye-shadow compacts up your sleeve
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: You see for a few months back when I was 16, shoplifting was the hottest craze at my suburban girls school
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It spread like a virus through Year 11, to the point that students would pop into town at lunch and return with a huge cache of stolen goods
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: They'd upturn the contents of their bags on to a desk with a shout of:"Who wants what?"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Now, the thieves providing the British Retail Consortium with a headache this week with their high-cost hauls are more likely to be professional "steal to order" shoplifters, not a gang of feckless teenage girls
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nevertheless
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it instantly brought back that rush of adrenaline that always follows a bout of five-finger discount "shopping"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It all began with a couple of girls nicking a few small items of makeup and jewellery
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: - and then we realised how easy it was
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It was almost impossible to get caught
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Why choose one eyeshadow, when you could have it in every colour?
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Why bother trying to find the right shade of foundation, when you could just take one of each?
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In any case, there would always be someone at school who would want it - or at least be impressed by it
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As the weeks went by things escalated
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We went after bigger prizes
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I vividly remember the thrill of the day I walked out of Topshop with two bikinis on under my clothes, alongside my best friend, brazenly wearing a stolen denim jacket over hers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We graduated from our local town centre to field trips to the nearest shopping mall
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: On the train back we would compare our hauls and swap stories
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: How
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the security guard didn't notice the Buffy the Vampire Slayer boxset stuffed up my mate's jumper
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: How the Venus razor blade hadn't set off the alarm in Boots, but in the book shop, leading to suspicious looks but escape
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: At school, when our teachers warned us that they wouldn't lend out French dictionaries to those who forgot to bring their own to the oral exam
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: we sent a couple of girls into town to empty WH Smith of its stock
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: On their return they defiantly plonked a stack on the desk for anyone who needed one
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I remember discussing what we should tell our parents when they asked questions about where our new clothes came from, but don't remember anyone raising the moral alarm
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Far from being unable to sleep at night, I would go to bed dreaming of new things to "jack" and innovative ways to do it
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Yes, I had worries about being caught but, as far as I can remember, there was no guilt whatsoever
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It seemed like the perfect victimless crime
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: After all
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we were stealing from chain stores that had plenty more
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Looking back
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it seems ludicrous that it ever felt so normal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What happened to us?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We weren't stealing through need
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: most of us got pocket money from our parents and had more than enough clothes to wear
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Maybe it was that particularly hot summer, or the pressure of our looming GCSEs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Or maybe we were greedy little consumerists with an overdeveloped sense of entitlement and no moral compass
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Who knows?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I would like to say we came to our senses and decided to stop
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that's not true
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The worst happened and two good friends were caught and arrested
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: They were let off with a caution
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: because their loot had included a GCSE maths revision guide
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: We're all upstanding members of the community now, with proper jobs and the inclination to pay for goods
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I've learned there' s no such thing as a victimless crime
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Stores close
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: prices go up
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: maybe wages get kept down because of losses due to shoplifting
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But habits built up during that summer of madness die hard
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I still occasionally find myself in a shop thinking: "How silly. If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they're not going to put a security tag on those expensive silk shirts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: they really shouldn't put them right near the door."
paragraphs.label: anecdote
